thread.title: Woman goes to incredible lengths for new iPhone
thread.title_full: Woman goes to incredible lengths for new iPhone

title: Woman goes to incredible lengths for new iPhone
text:
Email a friend 
WHY line up for a new iPhone in person like a pleb when you could get your iPad to do it for you? 
That’s the idea of one Sydney lady who has her iPad lining up for her outside Apple’s Australian flagship store on George Street in Sydney. 
The iPad is currently fourth in line at the store, with a long line queuing up behind her ready to be one of the first to grab Apple’s new iPhone 6s. 
Lucy Kelly is hoping to be the first “robot” to purchase an iPhone and set up her machine stand-in, with iPad attached , outside the store about 4am yesterday morning, The Daily Telegraph reported. 
Ms Kelly was chatting to confused passers-by from her home yesterday while she made Vegemite toast for breakfast. She said she would stay online throughout the day, and night, and make her way to the store this morning to buy the phone. Lucy Kelly has prime position in the Apple line thanks to her Atomic 212 robot, controlled remotely. AP Photo/Glenn Nicholls Source: AP 
She said Atomic 212, the media agency that she works for, had many of the robots around the office and came up with idea to put one out the front of the Apple store last week. 
“I want an updated version of the iPhone but I wasn’t going to wait in the cold and rain to get one,” she laughed. “I want to be the first robot to buy an iPhone.” 
With the iPhone 6s release today, telcos and Apple stores are expected to be inundated with iPhone fans on their Apple Christmas morning. 
Already, all models are sold out online from Apple and if you haven’t pre-ordered from a carrier it’s likely you’ll miss out on the most popular models. 
Limited stock is available at Apple stores on launch day, so, if you haven’t pre-ordered an iPhone 6s, you will have to get to your local store before midday if you want any chance of getting your hands on one. iPhone 
Despite it raining overnight hundreds have lined up outside Sydney’s Apple Store. 
With Australia being one of the few launch countries, the majority in the line have come from overseas to buy a device to bring back home. 
Most of them spent the night playing mahjong, like a first world hipster camp fire.
